attributes.title: Differences in extrinsic emotion regulation strategies based on emotion type, regulator and target sex.
attributes.description: This study investigates between-person emotion regulation of anger and anxiety, by examining the emotion regulation strategies people report that others use on them.

summary.value: While there is abundant literature investigating self-regulation of emotions, few studies have explored the use and effectiveness of extrinsic (other-regulation) emotion strategies. This study examines the emotion regulation strategies people report that others use on them, and the perceived effectiveness of these strategies. The preregistration is attached as a supplemental file, and outlines the aims, hypotheses, sample size, participant exclusion criteria, variables and data analysis that will be performed. No information has yet been collected for this study.

q3.value: Aiming to recruit about 85 participants via MTurk. Each participant will do a Flanker task, Cognitive Reflection task, random dot motion task, and surveys (Big-5, impulsivity, self-control) & demographics (age, gender, education, sleep, bilingualism). This project is primarily in the service of a hands-on, 1-week class for high school student. Here, the administrators are pre-registering a limited number of predictions. The students will also pre-register their predictions, which will be subject to corrections for multiple comparisons should interesting results emerge.

q4.value:
Administrator predictions:

1. CRT accuracy will correlate positively with conscientiousness (but possibly at a cost in RT), but neither RT nor accuracy in the CRT will correlate with any of the other Big 5 dimensions. Self-control and impulsivity will be positively and negatively correlated with CRT respectively. Amount of sleep will be examined as a secondary predictor.

2. Flanker interference (i.e., reactive control; >RT on incongruent vs congruent trials) will increase with neuroticism & impulsivity and decrease with extraversion and self-control. But conflict adaptation (i.e., the degree to which RT on accurate incongruent trials speeds up following immediately preceding correct incongruent trials; i.e., proactive control) will correlate positively with conscientiousness.. We will assess whether self-reported self-control differentially predicts proactive and reactive control.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q1.value: The extent to which the density of an individual's instrumental support network, and the gender split of one's support network predict workplace well-being

q2.value: Megan Dodd, Thomas V.  Pollet, Connor Malcolm

q3.value: Research has found that individuals form network ties with others who are similar to themselves and depending on what resources they need they will utilize their ties with these individuals in their network. A common use for network ties in the workplace is support seeking, those who receive support in the workplace display higher levels of workplace well-being than those who do not. No study has yet looked into the impact of support network density on workplace well-being. Previous studies looking at support in the workplace have looked specifically at emotional support and explored the impact gender has on attitudes, these studies have shown the importance of gender with regard to support in the workplace. The current study aims to develop previous research in the area, to determine if an individual’s workplace well-being can be improved depending on their support network density and the gender of those they go to for support. This study could help those who work in particularly stressful sectors ensure their quality of work isn’t negatively impacted due to poor workplace well-being.

q4.value: The hypotheses are directional. The hypothesis state that those who display a denser instrumental support network will score higher on workplace well-being. Also, those who have a support network that consists of more individuals with the same gender as themselves will also display a higher score of workplace well-being.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A non-experimental correlational design will be used. The predictor variables will be the density of instrumental support network and gender split of the support network. These variables will be used to explain the predicted variable, which is workplace well-being

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: G *power determined that in order to achieve a medium effect size a minimum of 68 participants must be recruited. Participants will be recruited via social media sites, a link to the questionnaire alongside a short message explaining what will be expected from potential participants, including inclusion information that will be posted on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. Participants will be required to be: a) at least 18 years old, and b) currently employed in either full time or part-time work. Participants who provide consent will be directed to complete the questionnaire.

q13.value: G Power determined that in order to achieve a medium effect size a minimum of 68 participants must be recruited.

q14.value: G Power determined that in order to achieve a medium effect size a minimum of 68 participants must be recruited.

q15.value: data collection will be terminated when 100 participants have been gathered, or on February 24th. Whichever is first.

question.value: A non-experimental correlational design will be used. The predictor variables will be the density of instrumental support network and gender split of the support network. These variables will be used to explain the predicted variable, which is workplace well-being. The Instrumental support network density will be calculated by using the formula (L/(n(n-1)/2)) (Scott, 2017). Multiple Linear regression (Enter method) will be used to determine if these two predictor variables predict workplace well-being. Bivariate correlations will be calculated. Workplace well-being will be measured by using the short SWELL questionnaire (Smith, 2017).

The Instrumental support network density will be calculated by using the formula (L/(n(n-1)/2)). In this study, the formula will only be run on the links made that do not include the Ego. The gender split of those in an individual’s support network will be determined by calculating the percentage of men and women in the network. Multiple Linear regression (Enter method) will be used to determine if these two predictor variables predict workplace well-being. Bivariate correlations will be calculated.

A non-experimental correlational design will be used. The predictor variables will be the density of instrumental support network and gender split of the support network. These variables will be used to explain the predicted variable, which is workplace well-being. Multiple Linear regression (Enter method) will be used to determine if these two predictor variables predict workplace well-being. Bivariate correlations will be calculated. ANOVA will determine is the correlation is significant. 

Dr? Thomas Pollet: It is possible that I'll do other analyses than the bachelor project. These might be the ones which end up in a published paper. In particular, I might conduct more complex social network analyses (including looking at other metrics). However, in the analysis document, I'll have the inclusion of a correlational analysis which examines the relationship between density and workplace well-being (1) and an examination of the correlational relation between gender homophily (% of support with same gender as ego) and workplace wellbeing (2). The hypotheses here are similar to those of Megan Dodd.

q1.value: Food wasting and preventing it - a new questionnaire

q3.value:
Household food wasting occurs when people fail to manage the surplus of food (a result of negligence or lack of concern). In contrast, preventing food wasting takes energy, time and consideration. To this date, most research on food wasting behaviour targeted the wasting process with little or no consideration towards the behaviours aimed at preventing food wasting (for review see: van Herpen, et al., 2019). 

In our study, we wanted to develop a cross-cultural questionnaire for measuring both the frequency of food wasting behaviours and the frequency of behaviours aimed at preventing food from being wasted. We argue, that measuring both aspects of food wasting behaviour may help researchers get a better picture of this phenomenon.

The United States Environmental Protection Agency argues that there are several levels of preventing food wasting: Food Recovery Hierarchy. 
1. Source reduction
2. Feeding hungry people
3. Feeding animals
4. Industrial uses
5. Composting

In our study, we wanted to verify whether peoples behaviours align along with these categories (except of Industrial uses - regular citizens are unable to use this method of preventing food waste).

In a previous study, based on existing research and responses of 177 participants, we identified: 
1. 52 behaviours that cause food waste in a household
2. 52 behaviours for preventing food waste

In the present study, 613 participants declared how frequently they engage in abovementioned behaviours. We plan to conduct an exploratory factor analysis and confirmatory factor analysis to test the hypothesis that there are four factors underlying behaviours aimed at reducing food wasting.

q4.value: 1. Avoiding food wasting behavior forms at least 4 factors (Prevention, Feeding humans, Feeding animals, Composting)

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: No blinding is involved in this study, although participants were not aware of the hypothesis.

question.value: Correlational study / scale development factor analysis

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The decision to pre-register was taken after data collection had begun. Data collection is now complete, but the data has not been cleaned for analysis, and no analysis has taken place.

question.value: We used the snowball sampling method. We advertised our link on facebook and in other social media. Participants were not paid for taking part in the study.

q13.value: We planned to conduct our research on at least 600 people. We gathered 613 responses, but we still don't know how many of them should be excluded because we didn't look for inattentive responses yet.

q14.value:
We planned to split the sample into two sub-groups. One for EFA and teh second for CFA.

Goretzko, Pham &; Bühner (2019) recommend samples of 400 for EFA but they also note that it is possible to conduct reliable EFA on samples of 300.

q15.value: We decided to stop promoting the study after reaching 600 responses. The link to the study was not disabled. Additional responses are the effect of the snowballing method.

question.value: n/a

We asked the participants to respond to 104 statements which described a behavior associated to food wasting or prevention of food wasting. Participants could declare how often they behave according to the statement on a 7-point Likert scale (1 - never, 7 - always). 
We asked about the age and gender of each participant to explore whether these two variables are associated with food wasting behavior or the behavior aimed at reducing food wasting.

We will conduct the exploratory factor analysis on the responses of 300 participants and the confirmatory factor analysis on the responses of remaining participants (both samples will be matched for gender and age).

We will divide our sample into two groups - 300 participants for exploratory factor analysis and the remaining participants for confirmatory factor analysis (318 participants minus irresponsive cases).

We will conduct exploratory factor analysis with the principal axis factoring and Promax rotation (according to recommendations provided by Goretzko, Pham and Bühner (2019)).

registration_responses.q1: Food wasting and preventing it - a new questionnaire
registration_responses.q3:
Household food wasting occurs when people fail to manage the surplus of food (a result of negligence or lack of concern). In contrast, preventing food wasting takes energy, time and consideration. To this date, most research on food wasting behaviour targeted the wasting process with little or no consideration towards the behaviours aimed at preventing food wasting (for review see: van Herpen, et al., 2019). 

In our study, we wanted to develop a cross-cultural questionnaire for measuring both the frequency of food wasting behaviours and the frequency of behaviours aimed at preventing food from being wasted. We argue, that measuring both aspects of food wasting behaviour may help researchers get a better picture of this phenomenon.

The United States Environmental Protection Agency argues that there are several levels of preventing food wasting: Food Recovery Hierarchy. 
1. Source reduction
2. Feeding hungry people
3. Feeding animals
4. Industrial uses
5. Composting

In our study, we wanted to verify whether peoples behaviours align along with these categories (except of Industrial uses - regular citizens are unable to use this method of preventing food waste).

In a previous study, based on existing research and responses of 177 participants, we identified: 
1. 52 behaviours that cause food waste in a household
2. 52 behaviours for preventing food waste

In the present study, 613 participants declared how frequently they engage in abovementioned behaviours. We plan to conduct an exploratory factor analysis and confirmatory factor analysis to test the hypothesis that there are four factors underlying behaviours aimed at reducing food wasting.

attributes.title: Factors Influencing the Assessment of Seriousness and Reporting Behavior of Leaking

q1.value: Factors Influencing the Assessment of Seriousness and Reporting Behavior of Leaking

q3.value:
Announcements prior to the offenses, also known as leakings, are an important warning sign for terrorist attacks, which (almost) all former perpetrators showed. This opens the possibility of police intervention, but in most cases, leaking occurs in the perpetrator's close social environment or online. Hence, leaking is not always easily accessible to the law enforcement agencies, so that the police has to rely on reports of leaking by relatives, friends, or others. It is, therefore, important to investigate which characteristics are considered as important for assessing the seriousness of leaking and the probability of reporting it. It seems that no study has ever examined the assessment of leaking prior to terrorist attacks and the factors which may influence the assessment and the reporting behavior by laypersons and law enforcement personnel. Therefore, we aim at examining the following research questions: 
1. What kind of information do laypersons and law enforcement personnel choose to assess the seriousness of leaking, in order to decide whether to report the behavior or not? 
2. How do different pieces of information influence the judged seriousness of the leaking, the probability of reporting it to the police and the perceived certainty? 
3. Which factors of the participants themselves influence the assessment of the seriousness of leaking, the probability of reporting leaking, and the perceived certainty regarding the assessment and when reporting leaking? 
4. Do police students and laypersons differ in the selection of information?

q4.value:
Regarding to the information chosen by the participants, we expect: 
- H1: Participants tend to choose information first that correspond with the stereotype of a terrorist (especially religious affiliation, ethnicity, criminal history) rather than the other available information (although research suggests that especially the repetition of crime announcements is a warning sign and therefore important information). 

Regarding to the influence of the selected information, we expect:
- H2a: The following characteristics of the alleged perpetrator to increase the judged seriousness of the leaking and the self-expected probability of reporting the leaking to the police: male, single, 20 years old (as contrasted to being 55 years old), right-wing attitude, Muslim religious affiliation, Arabic ethnicity, previous conviction, repetition of leaking (regardless of which other information is already known to the participant).
- H2b: The following characteristics to decrease the judged seriousness of the leaking and the probability of reporting the leaking to the police: female, in a relationship, no extremist political view, no criminal history, no previous leaking (regardless of which other information is previously known to the participant).
- H2c: The following characteristics not to influence judged seriousness of the leaking and the probability of reporting the leaking to the police: no religious affiliation, Caucasian ethnicity, 55 years old (regardless of which other information is previously known to the participant).
- H3: The increase in subjective certainty for seriousness and certainty of reporting behavior to be greater for characteristics that are consistent with the stereotype of a terrorist than for other available information.

Regarding characteristics of the participants we expect: 
- H4: Higher fear of terrorism to result in a higher judged seriousness of the leaking and a higher probability of reporting the leaking to the police. 
- H5: Female and older participants to assess the seriousness of the leaking higher and to be more likely to report the leaking to the police than male and younger participants. 
- H6: More consumption of news in the social media to correlate with a higher willingness to report and a higher judged seriousness of leaking (especially in combination with a more right-wing attitude and no Muslim or Arabic friends).

Regarding to the comparison of police students and laypersons we expect: 
- H7: Police students to choose the information about the repetition of leaking and previous criminal behavior more frequently than laypersons.
- H8: Police students to report an overall higher willingness to report leaking to the police and to feel more secure about doing so and about rating the seriousness of leaking.

question.value:
The study is conducted as an online-study. The study is advertised with flyer at two universities, Psychologische Hochschule Berlin and Heinrich Heine University Düsseldorf and via social media. For their participation, participants can take part in a lottery of gift cards. Participants must be at least 16 years old. Moreover, the study is also advertised in police academies. 

Procedure of the online-study: 
First, participants had to answer questions about their demographic background, consumption of news and their relationship to people of different migration backgrounds and political attitude. Then they were informed that a person had posted one statement on Facebook. They had to decide whether they would report the statement to the police and how serious they assess the post in terms of showing a danger of committing a terrorist attack. They had to assess the seriousness of the post and decide whether they would report the posting to the police on a 10-point Likert scale. For both assessments, participants were also asked to state their certainty of judgment on a scale between 0 and 100%. On the next page, participants were informed, that they have the possibility to select up to four additional pieces of information about the person who had posted the statement. They could select one information out of eight: age, gender, ethnicity, relationship, religious affiliation, political attitude, criminal history, and repetition of such postings. The categories were shown in a randomized order and after the participants had selected one category, it was no longer shown on the next page, where participants could choose another information. Participants could also choose not to receive any further information. For each selected category, one out of two possible information was randomly shown on the next page and they had to assess the seriousness, the decision to report it and their certainty of the decisions again. After having selected up to four additional pieces of information and assessing the posting five times, or after having stated that no further information is needed, the task was finished and participants had to answer questions about their fear of terrorism. Finally, participants had to answer the “Perceptions of Terrorism Questionnaire Short-Form” (PTQ-SF; Sinclair & LoCicero, 2006).

q13.value: Our target sample size is 300 participants (laypersons) and 200 police students.

q15.value: Data collection will be terminated by time frame. The data collection for the study with laypersons will stop on 27th of January at the latest.

question.value:
- Information shown after selection: We manipulated the pieces of information shown after the selection of one category. After participants had chosen one category, one of two information is randomly shown. We expect one of the pieces of information to increase the assessment of seriousness and the reporting behavior.

Information that could be shown
Ethnicity: Arabic ethnicity, Caucasian ethnicity 
Age: 20 years old, 55 years old 
Gender: male, female 
Religious affiliation: Muslim affiliation, no religious affiliation 
Political view: right-wing attitude, no extremist political view
Relationship status: single, in a relationship 
Previous conviction: previous conviction, no criminal history 
Repetition of the posting: repetition of leaking, no previous leaking

Outcome variables: 
- Order of information selection: measured as ranked scores. Information categories, participants choose, will be transformed into a rank system. The piece of information which was selected first receives 4 points. The piece of information which participants chose next receives 3 points, and so on. Non-selected items receive 0 points. 
- Assessment of seriousness and its change: measured with a 10-point Likert scale (1 = not serious/not dangerous to 10 = very serious/very dangerous) and computing the difference after each presentation of new information.
- Probability of reporting the leaking to the police and its change: measured with a 10-point Likert scale (1 = not at all to 10 = in any case) and computing the difference after each presentation of new information. 
- Certainty of judgement for seriousness and its change: measured from 0% (uncertain) to 100% (certain) and computing the difference after each presentation of new information. 
- Certainty of judgement for reporting behavior and its change: measured from 0% (uncertain) to 100% (certain) and computing the difference after each presentation of new information.

Predictors 
- Fear of terrorism: measured via questions about emotional, rational and behavioral fear of terrorism with a 7-point Likert scale. A total score will be computed by summing the answers of each question. 
- News consumptions TV, radio, printed newspaper, websites, social media: each measured with a 7-point Likert scale (1 = never to 7 = always)
- Political view: measured with a 7-point Likert scale (1= left-wing to 7 = right-wing) 
- Friends with different migration backgrounds and political views: dichotomous item for each question Covariates/Moderators: 

Other covariates: 
- Religious affiliation: Christian vs. Non-christian 
- Migration background: migration background vs. no migration background 
- Age
- Gender: male vs. female 
- Educational level

- Fear of terrorism: A score for each aspect of fear of terrorism (emotional, rational and behavioral fear of terrorism) will be computed by summing the answers of each question. The scores for emotional, rational and behavioral fear of terrorism are summed to a total score for the construct fear of terrorism. 
- News consumption: A total score will be computed by summing the answers of each item. 
- Perceptions of Terrorism Questionnaire Short-Form (PTQ-SF): 8 scales (terrorist mental illness, terrorist skill/capability, fear/impact of terrorism, impact of terror alerts, anger/lack of tolerance, perceived threat, desire to understand reasons for terrorism, faith in government for protection) measured with a 6-point Likert scale (1= not at all to 6 = extremely), 25 questions. The scores are computed by recoding those items which are reversed-scored, summing all items within each scale and transforming these scores to a 0-100 metric.

H1: Participants tend to choose information first that correspond with the stereotype of a terrorist (especially religious affiliation, ethnicity, criminal history) rather than the other available information (although research suggests that especially the repetition of crime announcements is a warning sign and therefore important information). 
- Friedman’s ANOVA
- Wilcoxon signed ranks test (follow-up pairwise comparison) 

H2a: TThe following characteristics of the alleged perpetrator to increase the judged seriousness of the leaking and the self-expected probability of reporting the leaking to the police: male, single, 20 years old, right-wing attitude, Muslim religious affiliation, Arabic ethnicity, previously conviction, repetition of leakings.
H2b: The following characteristics to decrease the judged seriousness of the leaking and the probability of reporting the leaking to the police: female, in a relationship, no extremist political view, no criminal history, no previous leaking. 
H2c: The following characteristics not to influence judged seriousness of the leaking and the probability of reporting the leaking to the police: no religious affiliation, Caucasian ethnicity, 55 years old.
- t-tests against 0 for each option 
- dependent variable: difference in assessment of seriousness; difference in probability of reporting the leaking 
- Correction for α-cumulation: Bonferroni-Holm method   

H3: The increase in subjective certainty for seriousness and certainty of reporting behavior to be greater for characteristics that are consistent with the stereotype of a terrorist than for other available information.
- Repeated-measured ANOVA:  
- Independent variable: characteristics (consistent with the stereotype of a terrorist (Muslim, Arab, right-wing attitude, criminal history, repetition of such postings) vs. other characteristics)
- Dependent variable: subjective certainty for reporting behavior, subjective certainty for seriousness assessment

H4: Higher fear of terrorism to result in a higher judged seriousness of the leaking and a higher probability of reporting the leaking to the police. 
- 1. Linear regression 
- Outcome: assessment of seriousness assessment 
- Predictor: fear of terrorism 
- Controlled for gender, age, migration background, religious affiliation, news consumption 
- 2. Linear regression 
- Outcome: reporting behavior  
- Predictor: fear of terrorism 
- Controlled for gender, age, migration background, religious affiliation, news consumption, educational background 

H5: Female and older participants to be more likely to report the leaking to the police than male and younger participants.
- 1. Linear multiple regression 
- Outcome: reporting behavior 
- Predictor: age, gender

H6: More consumption of news in the social media to correlate with a higher willingness to report and a higher judged seriousness of leaking (especially in combination with a more right-wing attitude and no Muslim or Arabic friends).
- 1. Linear multiple regression: 
- Outcome: reporting behavior 
- Predictor: consumption of news in social media, right-wing attitude
- 2. Linear multiple regression: 
- Outcome: assessment of seriousness 
- Predictor: consumption of news in social media, right-wing attitude, Muslim/Arabic friends 

H7: Police students to choose the information about the repetition of leaking and previous criminal behavior more frequently than laypersons.
- Chi-square test 

H8: Police students to report an overall higher willingness to report leaking to the police and to feel more secure about doing so and about rating the seriousness of leaking. 
- MANOVA: 
- Independent variable: group (police students/laypersons)
- Dependent variable: probability of reporting the leaking, certainty of reporting, certainty of the judged seriousness

q22.value: Participants will be excluded from final data analysis if they did not finish the study. Moreover, participants that show suspicious answering patterns will be considered for exclusion.

- Repeated-measured ANOVA:  
- Independent variable: characteristics (consistent with the stereotype of a terrorist (Muslim, Arab, right-wing attitude, criminal history, repetition of such postings) vs. other characteristics)
- Dependent variable: subjective certainty for reporting behavior, subjective certainty for seriousness assessment

H4: Higher fear of terrorism to result in a higher judged seriousness of the leaking and a higher probability of reporting the leaking to the police. 
- 1. Linear regression 
- Outcome: assessment of seriousness assessment 
- Predictor: fear of terrorism 
- Controlled for gender, age, migration background, religious affiliation, news consumption 
- 2. Linear regression 
- Outcome: reporting behavior  
- Predictor: fear of terrorism 
- Controlled for gender, age, migration background, religious affiliation, news consumption, educational background 

H5: Female and older participants to be more likely to report the leaking to the police than male and younger participants.
- 1. Linear multiple regression 
- Outcome: reporting behavior 
- Predictor: age, gender

H6: More consumption of news in the social media to correlate with a higher willingness to report and a higher judged seriousness of leaking (especially in combination with a more right-wing attitude and no Muslim or Arabic friends).
- 1. Linear multiple regression: 
- Outcome: reporting behavior 
- Predictor: consumption of news in social media, right-wing attitude
- 2. Linear multiple regression: 
- Outcome: assessment of seriousness 
- Predictor: consumption of news in social media, right-wing attitude, Muslim/Arabic friends 

H7: Police students to choose the information about the repetition of leaking and previous criminal behavior more frequently than laypersons.
- Chi-square test 

H8: Police students to report an overall higher willingness to report leaking to the police and to feel more secure about doing so and about rating the seriousness of leaking. 
- MANOVA: 
- Independent variable: group (police students/laypersons)
- Dependent variable: probability of reporting the leaking, certainty of reporting, certainty of the judged seriousness

attributes.title: Heart 2 Heart: Examining effects of parent-infant interaction on emotion and physiological regulation in dyads where the mother has anxiety

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: The Heart 2 Heart study: examining effects of mother-infant interaction on emotion and physiological regulation in dyads where the mother has anxiety.

other.value: An exploratory hypothesis for examination is that infants of mothers with different anxiety disorders will show differential affect and arousal responses to social-anxiety and general-anxiety eliciting stimuli respectively. The dependent variable will be physiological instability, as with main hypothesis (2).

sample.value:
Our sample size aim is 80 participants. The sample size was calculated from existing comparable data on the primary outcome's dependent variable (‘synchrony’). The data was from a previous study using the same protocol as outlined here, but with a community sample (Smith et al., 2019). Our previous analyses looked at group differences of infants by higher/lower maternal anxiety by conducting a median split of the GAD-7 (Spitzer, Kroenke, Williams, & Löwe, 2006), a dimensional measure of anxiety. Using dyadic cross-correlation of arousal as the primary outcome measure, we calculated Cohen’s D to be .53. With an alpha of .05, power was calculated at ~70%. This indicates acceptability given the DV’s effect size is anticipated to be higher in the present study, given the greater severity of anxiety in clinical versus community populations. Research increasingly suggests greater anxiety associates with greater synchrony (Beebe et al., 2011; Granat, Gadassi, Gilboa-Schechtman, & Feldman, 2017). 

References:
1. Beebe, B., Steele, M., Jaffe, J., Buck, K. A., Chen, H., Cohen, P., ... Feldstein, S. (2011). Maternal anxiety symptoms and mother–infant self‐ and interactive contingency. Infant Mental Health Journal, 32(2), 174–206.
2. Granat, A., Gadassi, R., Gilboa-Schechtman, E., & Feldman, R. (2017). Maternal Depression and Anxiety, Social Synchrony, and Infant Regulation of Negative and Positive Emotions. Emotion, 17(1), 11–27.
3. Smith, C. G., Jones, E. J. H., Charman, Tony, Clackson, K., Mirza, F. U., & Wass, S. V. (2019). Anxious parents show higher physiological synchrony with their infants. DOI: 10.31234/osf.io/m2rsg.
4. Spitzer, R. L., Kroenke, K., Williams, J. B., & Löwe, B. (2006). A brief measure for assessing generalized anxiety disorder: the GAD-7. Archives of Internal Medicine, 166(10), 1092–1097.

analyses.value:
Pilot analyses will be conducted after the first five dyads’ data has been collected to confirm data acquisition, e.g. the signals acquired are of a sufficiently high quality to conduct statistical analyses.

Demographic information and questionnaire scores will be summarised with percentages and means (standard deviations) following the standard published protocols. The specific questionnaires are: the Comprehensive Parenting Behaviour Questionnaire (CPBQ; Majdandžić, De Vente, & Bögels, 2016) the Infant Behaviour Questionnaire (IBQ; Gartstein & Rothbart, 2003), the GAD-7 (Spitzer et al., 2006), the PHQ-9 (Kroenke, Spitzer, & Williams, 2001), as well as a non-psychometric family background questionnaire used to gather demographic information. The SCID-V-RV (First et al., 2015) will be used to establish clinical characteristics and categorisations.  

Preprocessing of data from the autonomic reactivity device, measuring actigraphy, body temperature, heart rate monitor and GPS, will be conducted in MATLAB using protocols developed and tested in previous studies (Wass, Porayska-Pomsta, & Johnson, 2011; Wass et al., 2019). Planned analyses will include averaging movement, heart rate data and noise levels to create a single, per-participant average.

We will conduct cross-correlations to examine the relationship between continuous changes in environmental noise and continuous changes in dyads’ physiological activity. For examples of similar cross-correlation analyses see Smith et al. (2019) and Wass et al. (2019).

Analyses of the data collected from the microphone will examine the spectral and semantic content of the data recorded. Vocal coding of affect will also be analysed from the audio data. In addition, using MATLAB scripts, the total levels of auditory noise will be calculated, and the auditory complexity of the environment will be examined. An example of a mother and infant data sample is attached.

For mother-infant interaction episodes, we will analyse data by coding according to the Coding Interactive Behaviour manual (CIB; Feldman, 2003, 2007) and coding schemes used in studies with the same behavioural tasks as in our protocol. Reliability will be determined by calculating the intraclass correlation for ratings made by two coders to approximately 15% of the tapes randomly drawn.

References:
1. Feldman, R. (2003). Infant-Mother and Infant-Father Synchrony: The Coregulation of Positive Arousal. Infant Mental Health Journal, 24(1), 1–23.
2. Feldman, R. (2007). Parent–infant synchrony and the construction of shared timing; physiological precursors, developmental outcomes, and risk conditions. Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry, 48(3–4), 329–534.
3. First, M. B., Williams, J. B. W., Karg, R. S., & Spitzer, R. L. (2015). User’s Guide for the Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5 Disorders, Research Version (SCID-5-RV). Arlington, VA: American Psychiatric Association.
4. Gartstein, M. A., & Rothbart, M. K. (2003). Studying infant temperament via the revised infant behavior questionnaire. Infant Behavior and Development, 26(1), 64–86.
5. Kroenke, K., Spitzer, R. L., & Williams, J. B. (2001). The PHQ‐9: validity of a brief depression severity measure. Journal of General Internal Medicine, 16(9), 606–613.
6. Majdandžić, M., De Vente, W., & Bögels, S. M. (2016). Challenging parenting behavior from infancy to toddlerhood: Etiology, measurement, and differences between fathers and mothers. Infancy, 21(4), 423–452.
7. Smith, C. G., Jones, E. J. H., Charman, Tony, Clackson, K., Mirza, F. U., & Wass, S. V. (2019). Anxious parents show higher physiological synchrony with their infants. DOI: 10.31234/osf.io/m2rsg.
8. Spitzer, R. L., Kroenke, K., Williams, J. B., & Löwe, B. (2006). A brief measure for assessing generalized anxiety disorder: the GAD-7. Archives of Internal Medicine, 166(10), 1092–1097.
9. Wass, Sam V., Porayska-Pomsta, K., & Johnson, M. H. (2011). Training Attentional Control in Infancy. Current Biology, 21(18), 1543–1547.
10. Wass, S. V., Smith, C. G., Clackson, K., Gibb, C., Eitzenberger, J., & Mirza, F. U. (2019). Parents mimic and influence their infant’s autonomic state through dynamic affective state matching. Current Biology, 29(14), 2415-2422.
11. Wass, S. V., Smith, C. G., Daubney, K. R., Suata, Z. M., Clackson, K., Begum, A., & Mirza, F. U. (2019). Influences of environmental stressors on autonomic function in 12‐month‐old infants: understanding early common pathways to atypical emotion regulation and cognitive performance. Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry, 60(12), 1323-1333.

outliers.value:
Exclusion criteria are as follows: (1) when the adult primary diagnosis is schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, tics, autism, learning disability, or where the patient has severe depression with suicidal behaviour as assessed by clinician (NB: problems with depression, mood, trauma or schizo-affective presentations will be allowed, as long as they are not the sole diagnosis); (2) cardiovascular conditions, i.e. a history of coronary heart disease, a prior heart attack, uncontrolled hypertension, abnormal heart valves, congenital heart disease or heart muscle disease; (3) severe skin allergies; (4) unable to give informed consent; (5) infant or parent age outside 4-12 mos (infant) or 18-65 years (parent). 

Outliers will be excluded on the basis of the >2 IQR (Inter-Quartile Range) criterion.

dependent.value:
Key independent variable for hypothesis (1): 'synchrony,' indexed by the dyad's cross-correlation of a physiological arousal composite. 

Key independent variable for hypothesis (2): 'physiological instability,' indexed by changes in autonomic reactivity, including heart rate (HR), heart rate variability (HRV), actigraphy.

conditions.value: There are no conditions within this study.

hypothesis.value:
There are two main hypotheses:
(1) Relative to dyads with a mother with less severe anxiety, during activities of daily life the physiological activity of dyads with greater anxiety will be characterised by greater synchrony.
(2) Relative to dyads with a mother with less severe anxiety, the physiological activity of dyads with more severe anxiety will be characterised by more instability.

study_type_other.value: This study is to be conducted in partial fulfilment of the degree of Doctor of Philosophy (PhD).

attributes.title: Utterance informativity
attributes.description: Communication depends in part on the hope that people will tell us things we’re interested in with language providing a channel by which speakers can convey, among other things, newsworthy and informative messages. Despite this, research often emphasises the role of predictability, showing that comprehenders make fast and sophisticated use of knowledge about typical situations to shape their expectations about upcoming words in fine-grained and context-driven ways. This new study contrasts these two dimensions, distinguishing knowledge about situation plausibility from knowledge about what people actually choose to talk about.

q1.value: If you don't have anything nice (or interesting!) to say, don't say anything at all

q2.value: Hannah Rohde, Michael Franke, Jet Hoek

q3.value:
Communication depends in part on the hope that people will tell us things we’re interested in with language providing a channel by which speakers can convey, among other things, newsworthy and informative messages. Despite this, research often emphasises the role of predictability, showing that comprehenders make fast and sophisticated use of knowledge about typical situations to shape their expectations about upcoming words in fine-grained and context-driven ways. This new study contrasts these two dimensions, distinguishing knowledge about situation plausibility from knowledge about what people actually choose to talk about.

The question is one about modelling: What if an emphasis on event plausibility misses part of the picture? Can models be adapted to simultaneously incorporate expectations for newsworthiness alongside (and related to) expectations for event plausibility? The intuition is that listeners track the plausibility of situations in part to help them guess what a speaker is likely to select as a message worth conveying (e.g., a unicorn is rare but if one appeared, you’d be likely to mention it). The likelihood of mention is thus predicted to rise with the improbability of the situation. Indeed, recent models of the context-dependent meaning of gradable adjectives like 'tall' or 'big' assume that the cost of uttering a (positive form) adjective has to be traded-off against the prior probability of the actual degree (height, size, etc.) of the object in question, thus giving rise to a meaning of, say, 'tall' similar to “taller than the minimal point where the surprisal of seeing a person that tall licenses that the speaker has not said nothing at all”. Comprehenders in fact do show surprisal for content that is too uninformative if they are expecting novelty, suggesting they are predicting upcoming words based in part on the simple fact that a speaker has chosen the current message as one worth saying out loud. To test if comprehenders use a speaker’s choice to speak in guessing upcoming words, we compare their guesses in a sentence about what a character knows/believes and a sentence about what that the character has said.

q4.value:
General hypothesis:
People use real-world knowledge to estimate probable situations, and use these guesses to estimate what kind of messages would be worth uttering.

Specific hypothesis:
When prompted to guess what kind of situation a speaker will describe, participants will more often select a high (i.e. more remarkable) number when the speaker announces something out of the blue compared to when they report something in response to a question.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Our forced-choice task has a within subjects design with 1 factor (speaker initiative) with two levels ('out of the blue' vs 'when asked')

q9.value: The condition participants see each item in and the order in which they see the items will be completely randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will recruit participants through Amazon Mechanical Turk. 

Before the actual experiment starts, participants fill out a background questionnaire. Since we only want to include native speakers of English, participants will be excluded from the analysis if they answered 'yes' to the following question:

"Was there any other language besides English spoken in the home before the age of 6?"

Note: participants who answer 'yes' to this question will still complete the experiment and get paid for doing so.

In addition, we will include 4 'catch' trials that have obvious correct answers (e.g., the number of hours in a day) to check participants' performance. Participants who do not get the catch trials correct will be excluded from the analysis.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 100 native speakers of English.

q14.value: Based on the results of a previous like-minded pilot study, where we found an effect size of 0.4, we estimated power for a similar data and hierarchical logistic regression model, but for a smaller effect size of 0.25. Based on simulations using the package ’simr’ (Green & MacLeod 2015, Methods in Ecology and Evolution), we estimate that 100 participants should given us power of above 90%.

question.value:
Participants are presented with forced-choice fill-in-the-blank items. We manipulate whether a character is said to announce something OUT OF THE BLUE, or because they were ASKED.

     Erin is a first grade student in primary school.
     Erin has an uncle, Josh.
     Yesterday, when asked about it,  Josh said that there are ______ children in Erin's class. /
     Yesterday, Josh out of the blue said that there are ______ children in Erin's class.

                            20           28

Our outcome variable is the number participants select. In each item, participants can choose from 2 numbers: an average or a high number.

The numbers are based on a pre-test where we ask another group of participants (n = 20) about their a priori expectations about quantities:

     Erin is a first grade student in primary school.
     How many children are in Erin's class?

Participants are asked to supply a best guess, a minimum, and a maximum estimate of the left-out value in each item. We include 35 items in the pre-test.

For the experiment, we base our 'average' values on the mean of the 'best guess' responses provided in the pre-test. We set the 'high' value to the best guess mean + 1SD. We use the 'maximum' responses to make sure that the best guess mean + 1SD does not result in a value that by far exceeds the (mean) maximum value deemed plausible.

We will round the average and high values to the nearest round number. We will make an exception when only one of the values (either average or high) for a specific item result in a multiple of 5. In that case, we will round one of the values to the closest other round number to make sure that both values are either a multiple of 5 or not. This exception is based on findings that 'random-seeming' numbers tend to get a more punctual interpretation than numbers that are a multiple of 5 or 10 (e.g., Cummins 2019). Making sure that both the average and the high value for an item seem equally 'punctual' avoids a potential confound of punctual values (versus estimates) seeming more informative (for instance because saying that someone did 17 loads of laundry not only provides information about the number of times someone did laundry, but also implies that the speaker somehow counted/obtained/remembered the exact number).

We will analyze participants' responses (average vs. high) using mixed effects logistic regression.

The predictor variable Speaker Initiative (out of the blue vs. when asked about it) will be dummy coded and centered. We will include random item and participant variables.

In case the model does not converge, we will remove the correlation between the slope and the intercept for the random variable with the least explained variance. If the model still not converges after the correlation between the random slope and the random intercept has been removed for each variable, will will remove the random variable with the least explained variance (following Barr et al. 2013).

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the mixed effects logistic regression analysis suggests that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

registration_responses.q1: If you don't have anything nice (or interesting!) to say, don't say anything at all
registration_responses.q2: Hannah Rohde, Michael Franke, Jet Hoek
registration_responses.q3:
Communication depends in part on the hope that people will tell us things we’re interested in with language providing a channel by which speakers can convey, among other things, newsworthy and informative messages. Despite this, research often emphasises the role of predictability, showing that comprehenders make fast and sophisticated use of knowledge about typical situations to shape their expectations about upcoming words in fine-grained and context-driven ways. This new study contrasts these two dimensions, distinguishing knowledge about situation plausibility from knowledge about what people actually choose to talk about.

The question is one about modelling: What if an emphasis on event plausibility misses part of the picture? Can models be adapted to simultaneously incorporate expectations for newsworthiness alongside (and related to) expectations for event plausibility? The intuition is that listeners track the plausibility of situations in part to help them guess what a speaker is likely to select as a message worth conveying (e.g., a unicorn is rare but if one appeared, you’d be likely to mention it). The likelihood of mention is thus predicted to rise with the improbability of the situation. Indeed, recent models of the context-dependent meaning of gradable adjectives like 'tall' or 'big' assume that the cost of uttering a (positive form) adjective has to be traded-off against the prior probability of the actual degree (height, size, etc.) of the object in question, thus giving rise to a meaning of, say, 'tall' similar to “taller than the minimal point where the surprisal of seeing a person that tall licenses that the speaker has not said nothing at all”. Comprehenders in fact do show surprisal for content that is too uninformative if they are expecting novelty, suggesting they are predicting upcoming words based in part on the simple fact that a speaker has chosen the current message as one worth saying out loud. To test if comprehenders use a speaker’s choice to speak in guessing upcoming words, we compare their guesses in a sentence about what a character knows/believes and a sentence about what that the character has said.
registration_responses.q4:
General hypothesis:
People use real-world knowledge to estimate probable situations, and use these guesses to estimate what kind of messages would be worth uttering.

Specific hypothesis:
When prompted to guess what kind of situation a speaker will describe, participants will more often select a high (i.e. more remarkable) number when the speaker announces something out of the blue compared to when they report something in response to a question.

q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

registration_responses.q13: Our target sample size is 100 native speakers of English.
registration_responses.q14: Based on the results of a previous like-minded pilot study, where we found an effect size of 0.4, we estimated power for a similar data and hierarchical logistic regression model, but for a smaller effect size of 0.25. Based on simulations using the package ’simr’ (Green & MacLeod 2015, Methods in Ecology and Evolution), we estimate that 100 participants should given us power of above 90%.

registration_responses.q8.question: Our forced-choice task has a within subjects design with 1 factor (speaker initiative) with two levels ('out of the blue' vs 'when asked')
registration_responses.q12.question:
We will recruit participants through Amazon Mechanical Turk. 

Before the actual experiment starts, participants fill out a background questionnaire. Since we only want to include native speakers of English, participants will be excluded from the analysis if they answered 'yes' to the following question:

"Was there any other language besides English spoken in the home before the age of 6?"

Note: participants who answer 'yes' to this question will still complete the experiment and get paid for doing so.

In addition, we will include 4 'catch' trials that have obvious correct answers (e.g., the number of hours in a day) to check participants' performance. Participants who do not get the catch trials correct will be excluded from the analysis.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Participants are presented with forced-choice fill-in-the-blank items. We manipulate whether a character is said to announce something OUT OF THE BLUE, or because they were ASKED.

     Erin is a first grade student in primary school.
     Erin has an uncle, Josh.
     Yesterday, when asked about it,  Josh said that there are ______ children in Erin's class. /
     Yesterday, Josh out of the blue said that there are ______ children in Erin's class.

                            20           28

Our outcome variable is the number participants select. In each item, participants can choose from 2 numbers: an average or a high number.

     How many children are in Erin's class?
